title: 103_hr2396
content:
The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State agencies can only use the financial records for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Civil damages may apply for unauthorized disclosure by state officers or employees. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows state agencies to use financial records for child support obligations. Civil damages may apply for unauthorized disclosure by state officers or employees. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows state agencies to use financial records for child support obligations. In any legal action, if liability is found, the defendant is liable to the plaintiff for damages, including punitive damages for willful or grossly negligent disclosure of financial records. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows state agencies to use financial records for child support obligations. In any legal action, if liability is found, the defendant may be liable for damages, including punitive damages for willful or grossly negligent disclosure of financial records. The term "depository institution" is defined in the section for purposes of this act. The term "financial record" is defined in the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978. The term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a state agency that handles child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies have access to and can use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer. The agency must provide written notice to the consumer before obtaining the report. State child support enforcement agencies must provide written notice to consumers before obtaining a consumer report for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. The Act is amended to define a State child support enforcement agency as a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. The text chunk discusses the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders, requiring orders to comply with state guidelines for health care costs of the child. The text chunk discusses the requirement for states to establish guidelines for health care coverage of children in child support orders. Each State must establish guidelines for health care coverage of children in child support orders, meeting minimum standards set by the Secretary. This includes specifying the contents of the order and distributing responsibility for costs. The curr_chunk discusses the details of child support orders related to healthcare costs, including the coverage, responsibility distribution, health insurance provisions, denial of coverage circumstances, penalties for non-compliance by insurance providers. The curr_chunk outlines guidelines for child support orders regarding healthcare costs, including coverage, parental financial circumstances, penalties for non-compliance, and changes in parents' situations. The Secretary must ensure the best interests of the child, parents' financial situations, and cost-effectiveness are considered in developing these standards. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue proposed and final regulations within specified timeframes to implement the guidelines for child support orders related to healthcare costs. Health and Human Services will issue final regulations to implement amendments related to the enforcement of support orders requiring an absent parent to obtain health insurance for children. This enforcement will be considered as support collection, regardless of how the support is provided. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue regulations to implement amendments for enforcing support orders requiring absent parents to provide health insurance for children. This enforcement will be considered as support collection, with the amount collected being the state's savings from providing health insurance to the children. Additionally, a study will be conducted to determine the impact of these regulations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to determine incentives for states to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. A report must be submitted to the House of Representatives Committee on Ways and Means within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to the House of Representatives and Senate committees on the results of a study regarding incentives for states to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses within 12 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STATE COMPLIANCE WITH TIME LIMITS FOR CHILD SUPPORT ASSISTANCE. Amends the Social Security Act to include compliance standards for states. 

SEC. 6. EMPLOYERS MUST WITHHOLD WAGES FOR CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS WITHIN 10 DAYS; PENALTY FOR LATE PAYMENTS. Amendment to the Social Security Act requires employers to withhold wages for child support payments within 10 days. Employers failing to do so will face a $1,000 penalty to be paid to the State. Penalties collected must be used for the State plan approved under section 454. The amendments to the Social Security Act require employers to withhold wages for child support payments within a specified timeframe. Penalties will be imposed on employers who fail to comply, with the collected penalties to be used for the State plan approved under section 454. The effective date for these amendments is the date of enactment of the Act, with certain exceptions for states requiring additional legislation. The amendments to the Social Security Act require employers to withhold wages for child support payments within a specified timeframe. Penalties will be imposed on employers who fail to comply, with the collected penalties to be used for the State plan approved under section 454. States needing additional legislation for compliance will not be penalized if requirements are met within a specified timeframe after the state legislature's regular session. The National Parent Locator Network is established under Section 7. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing states to locate absent parents for child support enforcement and visitation orders by accessing various databases. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing states to access various databases to locate absent parents for child support enforcement and visitation orders. This includes accessing federal sources of information, checking other states' files for additional child support orders, and providing both online and batch processing of locate requests. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing states to access databases for immediate information needs, batch processing, and locating individuals. It includes direct locate requests, broadcast requests, and a 48-hour turnaround time for information retrieval. Access to court information is facilitated through computer terminals in each court. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing states to access databases for immediate information needs, batch processing, and locating individuals. Access to court information is facilitated through computer terminals in each court. HR 2396 IH----2
